qas.question: What is the effect called when capacitors absorb sound waves?
What value of a capacitor is varied when vibration moves the conducting plates?
What sort of current is induced when the capacitance of a capacitor is altered?
In what type of applications is piezeoelectricity especially problematic?
What is it called when a changing electric field existing between the conductive plates of a capacitor physically moves them?
What is the effect called when capacitors don't absorb sound waves?
What value of a capacitor is not varied when vibration moves the conducting plates?
What sort of current is induced when the capacitance of a capacitor is unaltered?
In what type of applications is piezeoelectricity never problematic?
What is it called when a changing electric field existing between the conductive plates of a capacitor keeps them still?

context: Capacitors, especially ceramic capacitors, and older designs such as paper capacitors, can absorb sound waves resulting in a <a0_0><b5_0>microphonic effect<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Vibration moves the plates, causing <a1_0>the <b6_0>capacitance<b6_0/><a1_0/> to vary, in turn inducing <a2_0><b7_0>AC current<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Some dielectrics also generate piezoelectricity. The resulting interference is especially problematic in <a3_0><b8_0>audio applications<b8_0/><a3_0/>, potentially causing feedback or unintended recording. In <a4_0>the <b9_0>reverse microphonic effect<b9_0/><a4_0/>, the varying electric field between the capacitor plates exerts a physical force, moving them as a speaker. This can generate audible sound, but drains energy and stresses the dielectric and the electrolyte, if any.
